title: Review: WALSH – KARAOKE
content:
When Walsh’s Smoke weed about it EP was released last year it was a breath of fresh air. Combining elements of shoe-gaze, hip-hop and chill wave it ultimately formed a reverberating synths laden delight. Its main strength was its want and need to experiment. No one tune clung to a particular theme or style, yet the record as a whole still managed to cling to a sound. In this case: thoughts of a damaged metropolis.

Despite the genre jumping, each tune on the EP worked when compared to one another, in many ways they still do with his new record KARAOKE. The sound is still more focused but bizarrely loses the wonder that made his last EP a joy to listen to. The low-fi grooves are still interesting and Walsh can undoubtedly get your head bopping quicker and for longer than most, yet it all seems like a well-trodden formula.

Birthday Girl and Dark Future are two tracks that embrace the free-form personality of the last EP but as obnoxious as it sounds, the rest of the record comes across as lo-fi Justice B-sides, leaving the EP feeling mundane.
author: 5e9b68b27a1236eccfeb1d24
